The primary purpose of the Fieldwork Data Form is to summarize information regarding the program at a fieldwork site. Occupational therapy (OT) and occupational therapy assistant (OTA) students will find valuable information describing the characteristics of the fieldwork setting; the client population; commonly used assessments; interventions; and expectations and opportunities for students. The Fieldwork Data Form has been developed to reflect the Occupational Therapy Practice Framework: Domain and Process, 3rd Edition (American Occupational Therapy Association [AOTA], 2014) terminology and best practice in occupational therapy to promote quality fieldwork experiences. The data gathering processes used in completion of this form entails a collaborative effort that facilitates communication between OT and OTA academic programs, students, and fieldwork educators. This form may be completed by the combined efforts of the fieldwork educator, the OT or OTA student assigned to the site for fieldwork, and/or the Academic Fieldwork Coordinator (AFWC) from the program. Fieldwork sites are encouraged to update the form annually and provide a copy to the educational program(s) where they have a current memorandum of understanding (MOU).

The secondary purpose of the Fieldwork Data Form is to document the connection between the curriculum design of a given OT or OTA educational program with its fieldwork component. The AFWC will use the data entered on the form to document fieldwork related Accreditation Council for Occupational Therapy (ACOTE) Standards (ACOTE, 2012). The standards are outlined in Section C of the 2011 ACOTE standards and are denoted on the form. Educational programs can revise the form to suit the needs of their respective fieldwork programs.

The Fieldwork Data Form was developed through the joint efforts of the Commission on Education (COE) and the Academic Education (formerly Education) Special Interest Section Fieldwork Community of Practice with input from many dedicated AFWCs and fieldwork educators.

The primary purpose of the Fieldwork Data Form is to summarize information regarding the program at a fieldwork site. Occupational therapy (OT) and occupational therapy assistant (OTA) students will find valuable information describing the characteristics of the fieldwork setting; the client population; commonly used assessments; interventions; and expectations and opportunities for students. The Fieldwork Data Form has been developed to reflect the Occupational Therapy Practice Framework: Domain and Process, 3rd Edition (American Occupational Therapy Association [AOTA], 2014) terminology and best practice in occupational therapy to promote quality fieldwork experiences. The data gathering processes used in completion of this form entails a collaborative effort that facilitates communication between OT and OTA academic programs, students, and fieldwork educators. This form may be completed by the combined efforts of the fieldwork educator, the OT or OTA student assigned to the site for fieldwork, and/or the Academic Fieldwork Coordinator (AFWC) from the program. Fieldwork sites are encouraged to update the form annually and provide a copy to the educational program(s) where they have a current memorandum of understanding (MOU).

The secondary purpose of the Fieldwork Data Form is to document the connection between the curriculum design of a given OT or OTA educational program with its fieldwork component. The AFWC will use the data entered on the form to document fieldwork related Accreditation Council for Occupational Therapy (ACOTE) Standards (ACOTE, 2012). The standards are outlined in Section C of the 2011 ACOTE standards and are denoted on the form. Educational programs can revise the form to suit the needs of their respective fieldwork programs.

The Fieldwork Data Form was developed through the joint efforts of the Commission on Education (COE) and the Academic Education (formerly Education) Special Interest Section Fieldwork Community of Practice with input from many dedicated AFWCs and fieldwork educators.

Please rate the Preceptor in terms of the following:
Ability to modify teaching to meet student needs

Above Average
  • Provides director atleast line of site supervision initially
  • Modifies degree of supervision with student progress
  • Modifies degree of supervision as complexity of case load dictates

Average
  • Provides direct or at least line of site supervision initially
  • May not modify degree of supervision as student progress or complexity of patient dictates

Inadequate
  • Does not supervise student or Does not supervise enough or Does not
  • allow student any independence as student growth dictates

Above Average
  • Gives frequent constructive feedback in supportive, non-threatening manner Comments on both + and - performance
  • Feedback is specific and offers suggestions to improve
  • Provides formative and summative feedback
  • Independently modifies feedback based on student needs

Average
  • Gives constructive feedback
  • May require cueing from ACCE, CCCE or student to modify the frequency or amount of feedback to meet student needs May provide formative feedback but summative feedback only at midterm and final
• Provides feedback in a manner that is not constructive

Above Average
  • Clearly articulates students strengths and weaknesses
  • Able to pinpoint causes of performance issues

Average
  • Recognizes global strengths and weaknesses

Inadequate
  • Unable to identify strengths/weaknesses
  • Does not critically evaluate student performance

Above Average
  • Promptly modifies learning activities based on learner
  • Provides alternative learning experiences

Average
  • Able to provide effective learning experiences for the average student
  • May require guidance for student with additional needs
• Unable to provide acceptable learning experiences based on student needs

1. Highly Recommend for Future Placement
  • Offers varied case load and depth in speciality area
  • Structured clinical education program with support of clinical education
  • Offers additional experiences i.e.: journal club, extra skill sessions, formal in-service program, observe surgery, interdisciplinary approach Preceptors excellent professionals

2. Recommend for Future Placement
  • Varied case load
  • May be smaller facility which is unable to offer additional learning experiences such as interdisciplinary approach, surgery etc. Preceptors are acceptable profession

3. Recommend/Reservations
  • Lacks variety of case load
  • Quantity of case load may not be appropriate for some students
  • Isolated problem with one CI that may need intervention
  • Facility could offer a good experience with further development of clinical education program

4. Do Not recommend for Future
  • Unethical or illegal practices noted
  • Staff are not acceptable professional role models
